headline.seo: Albacore Roasted in a Bed of Lettuce — Recipes for Health
headline.main: Albacore Roasted in a Bed of Lettuce

docs.snippet: Saffron is optional in this dish, but it adds a Provençal flourish to the tomato and onion sauce that keeps the fish moist as it roasts.

headline.seo: Scholars Retract Another Study Linking XMRV to Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
headline.main: Scholars Retract Another Study Linking Virus to Fatigue Syndrome
headline.print_headline: Scholars Retract Another Study Linking Virus to Fatigue Syndrome

keywords.value: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Poisoning is now the leading cause of injury death, and 90 percent of poisonings were caused by drugs.

headline.seo: More Americans Died of Poisoning Than in Car Crashes in 2008
headline.main: Poisoning Kills More Than Car Crashes
headline.print_headline: Poisoning Kills More Than Car Crashes

docs.abstract: Analysis published by National Center for Health Statistics finds that more people died of poisoning than car crashes in 2008, making poisoning leading cause of death for first time in 30 years; 90 percent of poisonings were caused by drugs, indicating rise of abuse of opioid painkillers.
docs.snippet: Poisoning is now the leading cause of injury death, and 90 percent of poisonings were caused by drugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: New research helps explain why a person with face blindness may still have difficulty determining who a person is even after he or she has begun to speak.

headline.seo: Face and Voice Recognition May Be Linked in the Brain, Research Suggests
headline.main: Have We Met? Tracing Face Blindness to Its Roots
headline.print_headline: Have We Met? Tracing Face Blindness to Its Roots

docs.abstract: Katharina von Kriegstein study in Journal of Neuroscience finds that regions of brain associated with face recognition are directly linked to regions responsible for voice recognition; findings help explain why person with face-blindness may still fail to recognize someone even after they have spoken.
docs.snippet: New research helps explain why a person with face blindness may still have difficulty determining who a person is even after he or she has begun to speak.

docs.lead_paragraph: The biggest gains were made in Africa, where a vast majority of the deaths occur and where donor dollars have been concentrated.

headline.seo: W.H.O. Reports 25 Percent Drop in Malaria Deaths in a Decade
headline.main: Malaria: World Health Organization Says Deaths Have Dropped 25 Percent in Last Decade
headline.print_headline: Malaria: World Health Organization Says Deaths Have Dropped 25 Percent in Last Decade

docs.abstract: World Health Organization announces that malaria deaths have fallen by more than 25 percent in the last decade, thanks to a coordinated attack on the disease, but that progress remains fragile.
docs.snippet: The biggest gains were made in Africa, where a vast majority of the deaths occur and where donor dollars have been concentrated.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new analysis suggests that martinis and beer may be just as effective as wine at extending life.

headline.seo: Beer and Martinis: Just as Effective as Wine for Longevity?
headline.main: Prevention: Beer and Martinis: As Healthy as Wine?
headline.print_headline: Prevention: Beer and Martinis: As Healthy as Wine?

docs.abstract: Analysis of studies by Charles Holahan published in Journal of Studies on Alcohol and Drugs finds that martinis and beer may be just as effective at extending life as wine.
docs.snippet: A new analysis suggests that martinis and beer may be just as effective as wine at extending life.

docs.lead_paragraph: A change in your blood pressure during early middle age can significantly affect your lifetime risk for cardiovascular disease, according to a new study.

headline.seo: Blood Pressure Changes in Middle Age Can Affect Heart Risk
headline.main: Risks: Blood Pressure Tests May Not Be Enough
headline.print_headline: Risks: Blood Pressure Tests May Not Be Enough

docs.abstract: Study authored by Norrina Allen and published in journal Circulation finds that hypertension in early middle age increases risk for cardiovascular illness and suggests more rigorous blood pressure testing should be done to lower this risk.
docs.snippet: A change in your blood pressure during early middle age can significantly affect your lifetime risk for cardiovascular disease, according to a new study.

docs.lead_paragraph: While a diet high in sodium — salt is the main source — increases heart disease risk, even more important is the ratio of sodium (harmful) to potassium (protective).

headline.seo: High Sodium-to-Potassium Ratio in Diet Is a Major Heart Risk
headline.main: Sodium-Saturated Diet Is a Threat for All
headline.print_headline: Sodium-Saturated Diet Is a Threat for All

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column warns of persistent dangers posed by high-sodium diets, noting that those who take in large amount of sodium and relatively little potassium are particularly prone to hypertension and death; provides several recommendations, including eating less processed food.
docs.snippet: While a diet high in sodium — salt is the main source — increases heart disease risk, even more important is the ratio of sodium (harmful) to potassium (protective).

docs.lead_paragraph: When a federal panel asked two journals last week to withhold details on bird flu experiments, it was only the latest example of an ages-old conflict often rooted in issues of war and advanced weaponry.

headline.main: Science and Censorship: A Duel Lasting Centuries
headline.print_headline: Science and Censorship: A Duel Lasting Centuries

docs.abstract: Fraught relationship between science, censorship and government goes back centuries, often centering on issues of war and advanced weaponry; issue has again raised its head in the case of a federal advisory panel that has asked journals Science and Nature to withhold details of experiments out of fear terrorists could use the information to make deadly flu viruses; represents first time government has interceded this way in biomedical research.
docs.snippet: When a federal panel asked two journals last week to withhold details on bird flu experiments, it was only the latest example of an ages-old conflict often rooted in issues of war and advanced weaponry.
